journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Nanoscale analysis of tensile properties and fracture of nanoreinforced epoxy polymer using micromechanics

article-meta.aff: 1Smart Structures and Advanced Composites Laboratory, College of Aerospace and Civil Engineering, Harbin Engineering University, Harbin, China
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong

author-notes.corresp: Fang Liu, Smart Structures and Advanced Composites Laboratory, College of Aerospace and Civil Engineering, Harbin Engineering University, Harbin 150001, China. Email: Liufang_winter@163.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Tensile properties of nanocomposites (silica/epoxy) with some aggregations of nanosilica are studied by nanoscale simulation, particularly with regard to the effective modulus and tensile strength. Three analytical models are used to obtain the effective elastic modulus of nanoparticle-reinforced composites (silica/epoxy). Then a multi-scale finite element method is proposed to study the interaction of particles and matrix for silica/rubber/epoxy systems at the nanoscale near a crack tip. A multi-scale finite element model with effective homogeneous material properties is used to study the fracture of a compact tension sample. The simulation results for effective elastic modulus and tensile strength of SiO2 particle-reinforced epoxy composites, and fracture toughness at the nanoscale for SiO2/rubber/epoxy with various volume fractions, show good agreement with previously published experimental data. It is demonstrated that the proposed parametric model can be used to efficiently study the toughness mechanisms at the nanoscale.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Epoxy resin has been widely used in the aerospace field, as fiber-reinforced composite matrix and adhesive. Cured epoxy resin is a highly cross-linked polymer. However, the structure of thermosetting resin will lead to brittleness of the material, which determines the weak resistance to the fatigue loading. In recent years, many researchers have found through large numbers of experiments that adding nanoparticles to epoxy has some positive effects on the tensile properties, fracture toughness and energy release rate.1–6 Tang et al.1,2 added nano-SiO2 particles (diameter = 25 nm) and powdered rubber (PR) (diameter = 60 nm) to epoxy matrix to form nanoparticle-reinforced composites. Tensile tests for silica/epoxy systems and quasi-static fracture toughness tests for SiO2/rubber/epoxy systems were carried out. The results showed that both stiffness and tensile strength improved with increasing silica content for silica/epoxy, and toughness improved with increasing PR content for SiO2/rubber/epoxy.

However, some manufacturing-related factors such as particle/matrix interphases, surface modification, particle agglomeration, particle size and variation in properties of particles or matrix material may possibly lead to different toughness effects even for the identical types of particles and matrix materials. Along with the complex mechanisms involved, this makes it difficult to explain how each factor influences the stiffness, tensile strength and fracture toughness of nanocomposites and the relationship between the variation of constituents at the nanoscale and the performance change at the macroscale. Hence, a theoretical or numerical model including nanoscale particles and interphases is needed. Tensile simulation with some aggregations of nanosilica and multi-scale simulation from macroscale to nanoscale have the capability to help better understand the toughness mechanisms.

One objective of this paper is to study the effect of different volume contents of nanosilica on effective modulus and tensile strength of nanocomposites (silica/epoxy) with some aggregations of nanosilica by finite element method (FEM). Considering that nanoparticles cannot be completely uniformly distributed in the matrix actually, there will exist aggregation phenomena. Therefore, random location of nanoparticles should be taken into account in the simulation. As this is a two-dimensional (2D) analysis in this paper, the distribution of nanoparticles can be selected from any cutting-plane of the 3D model. Therefore, the randomness of nanoparticle sizes from zero to the whole particle size (25 nm) should also be introduced. In present work, python language is used for modeling programming to simulate the automatic generation of random distribution of nanoparticles. Besides, virtual crack closure technique (VCCT) and ductile damage criterion (considering some plastic performance of matrix) were used to simulate phenomena of nanoparticle debonding and matrix crack, according to the weak interface strengthening and toughening mechanisms, including filler debonding, and the subsequent void growth.7–12

Another objective of this work is to obtain fracture toughness of SiO2/rubber/epoxy and to study the interaction of particles and matrix for silica/rubber/epoxy systems at the nanoscale near a crack tip. FEM is an effective method to show the fracture at either the nano or macroscale, however, it is difficult to directly observe the visible crack extension and particle debonding in macroscale FE model. The reason is that the mesh in a test specimen such as a compact tension (CT) sample is too coarse to produce satisfactory results in the crack tip region at the nanoscale (although the results away from this region may be acceptable). A practical and effective approach may be used to solve this problem. That is, using the global–local method to study the relationship between macro-level characteristics and nanoscale parameters in nanoparticle-reinforced composites. In the present method, the key issue is how to determine the critical debonding condition and how to relate the macro experimental condition such as critical load to the nanoscale representative volume element (RVE) model.

sec.title: Calculation of tensile strength and effective modulus in micromechanics model
Description of RVE model for silica/epoxy
sec.p:
Considering the manufacturing-related factor (particle agglomeration), random distribution nanoparticles should be taken into account in RVE modeling. As shown in Figure 1, there are numerous cutting planes in the 3D model. Any cutting surface will intersect with particles inside 3D model. Since the position of the cutting surface is variable, the circle sizes of these particles intersected with the cutting-plane will be different. Therefore, considering these situations above, nanoparticle sizes in 2D model in this study are randomly ranging from zero to the whole particle size. Because it is a random distribution problem, the location of the particles in the 2D model is also random. Area fraction of nanoparticles is used in this 2D analysis, which is assumed equal to volume fraction. And in the generation of RVE, the given number of nanoparticles is determined by the size of RVE (300 nm × 300 nm) and nanoparticles (diameter = 25 nm), as well as area fraction. Figure 1.
Nanoparticles and the cutting-plane inside three-dimensional (3D) model.

In the present work, python language is used for modeling programming to simulate the automatic generation of random distribution and size of nanoparticles in ABAQUS CAE Environment. Figure 2 shows programming for generation of RVE. Figure 2.
Programming process for generation of representative volume element (RVE).

There are some restrictions for particles center generation to avoid particle overlapping: (a) the minimum distance between particle centers with each other is the particle diameter (25 nm). (b) The minimum distance between particle centers and RVE boundaries is the particle radius (12.5 nm).

Interfaces were assumed to be perfectly bonded with no separation as in most published simulations,13,14 regardless of whether considering a two-phase or a three-phase model. In the real world, different phases may debond when the stress or strain approaches the maximum allowable value. Hence, particle debonding from matrix is considered in this paper, with zero-thickness interphase.
The effective modulus and ultimate stress of the RVE can be calculated from the FE model. The accuracy can be estimated by comparing with the measured effective tensile results in Ref. [1].

sec.title: Analytical formulation of effective modulus
sec.p: Halpin and Tsai found that the modulus of particulate polymers can be predicted by the semi-empirical relationship15: (1)Ec/Em=1+A1B1Vp1-B1Vp where A1 and B1 are constants for a given composite. A1 is a function of the particle shape and matrix Poisson ratio and B1 is related to the modulus of the particle (Ep) and matrix (Em). Vp is the volume content of nanoparticles.

Guth16 added a particle interaction term in the Einstein equation which becomes: (2)Ec/Em=1+2.5Vp+14.1Vp2 where the linear term is the stiffening effect of individual particles and the second power term is the contribution of particle interaction.
Counto17 proposed a simple model for a two-phase particulate composite by assuming perfect bonding between ﬁller and matrix. The composite modulus is given by: (3)1/Ec=(1-Vp)/Em+1/[(1-Vp)/VpEm+Ep]

sec.title: Calculation of effective modulus and tensile strength by FEM
sec.p:
In this parametric FE model, a uniform matrix is considered following many scholars in the field of simulation study.18,19 Young’s modulus of matrix is 3.01 GPa according to Ref. [1], while Young’s modulus of 70 GPa20 is adopted for nanosilica. The Poisson’s ratios of matrix and particle are 0.3 and 0.2, respectively. And the diameter of particles is 25 nm. Represent volume element size selected here for modeling is 300 nm × 300 nm. Figure 3 shows RVE displacement-loading schematic. Nanoscale tensile stress analysis is completed by using ABAQUS. Many scholars agree the weak interface toughening and strengthening mechanism,7--12 which is adopted in this article. So the failure process of nanocomposites here is simulated by interface debonding at first and then matrix failure. Accordingly, debonding at the interfaces of different materials is assumed. Here, particle debonding is achieved by VCCT. Interfaces, with zero thickness, debonded with respect to the energy criterion. When the critical strain energy release rate of interphase is met, interfacial debonding will occur. Although neat epoxy has low fracture toughness, it still has some plastic performance which may be less obvious. Considering its ductility, initiation and evolution of matrix failure used the ductile damage criterion and fracture energy criterion, respectively. Figure 3.
Representative volume element (RVE) displacement-loading schematic.

sec.title: Comparison from analytic and numerical models with experimental results
sec.p:
Tang et al.1 used tensile tests to obtain the effective modulus and tensile strength of SiO2/epoxy. The calculated results obtained from equations (1) to (3) and FE models are compared with the test results1 in Tables 1 and 2. The improvement of tensile properties versus volume fraction are shown in Figure 4(a) and (b). It is shown that the 2D RVE model has good accuracy for tensile simulation, further demonstrating the validity of modeling assumption. Stress–strain curves for different nanosilica contents and tensile failure of RVE are shown in Figures 5 and 6, respectively. Figure 4.
(a) The improvement of effective modulus versus volume fraction. (b) The improvement of tensile strength versus volume fraction.
Figure 5.
Stress–strain curves for different nanosilica contents.
Figure 6.
Tensile failure of representative volume element (RVE) for 12 vol.%.
Table 1.
Comparisons of effective modulus from simulation and 3 models.
Sample code Modulus (GPa)
Test1 Simulation Haipin-Tsai Counto Guth
EP 3.01 ± 0.05 – – – –
EP/Silica (97/3) 3.39 ± 0.19 3.48 3.26 3.49 3.27
EP/Silica (94/6) 3.42 ± 0.34 3.54 3.51 3.79 3.61
EP/Silica (91/9) 3.63 ± 0.11 3.70 3.79 4.07 4.03
EP/Silica (88/12) 3.95 ± 0.2 4.05 4.08 4.34 4.52
Table 2.
Comparisons of tensile strength from simulation.
Sample code Tensile strength (MPa)
Test1 Simulation
EP 67.49 ± 6.87 –
EP/Silica (97/3) 82.09 ± 4.78 77.30
EP/Silica (94/6) 86.88 ± 8.8 80.21
EP/Silica (91/9) 90.53 ± 2.45 88.36
EP/Silica (88/12) 98.07 ± 4.53 92.14

sec.title: Fracture analysis with multi-scale modeling for SiO2/rubber/epoxy
Load and boundary condition in fracture analysis
sec.p:
In this work, one type of macroscale fracture tests, the static CT test,2 with an initial crack utilized to measure the fracture toughness of composite specimens is simulated. The CT sample is a plate with 36 mm length, 36 mm width and 7.2 mm thickness,2 shown in Figure 7. The FE model of the CT sample is a simplified 2D model with the right edge limited not to move along horizontal direction through a node far away from the crack tip and a pair of critical tensile loads, Pc, is applied on the sample along the vertical direction, as shown in Figure 7. Due to the symmetry of geometry and loading, displacement for the half CT model, along vertical direction on the symmetry surface, is not allowed. Figure 7.
Multi-scale models of nanoreinforced composites for fracture analysis.

For fracture simulation of the CT sample, the effective tensile modulus is obtained from analytical formulation, equations (4) to (6). Based on equation (1) of modulus prediction for binary composites containing only one kind of particles, modified model considering the binary composite as the new matrix for ternary composites is utilized2: (4)Ec'/Em=1+A1B1V1+A2B2V2+A1B1V1A2B2V21-B1V1-B2V2+B1V1B2V2 in which (5)B1=(E1/Em)-1(E1/Em)+A1 (6)B2=(E2/Ec)-1(E2/Ec)+A2=(1-B1V1)E2-(1+A1B1V1)Em(1-B1V1)E2+(1+A1B1V1)EmA2 where E′c, Ec and Em are modulus of ternary composites, new matrix and first matrix (such as epoxy), respectively. V1 and V2 are volume fractions of two different types of particles, while E1 and E2 are modulus of these two. A1 is a function of the particle shape and matrix Poisson ratio (A1 = 2 for Spherical particles) and B1 is related to the modulus of the particle and matrix.

Analytical formulation, equations (4)–(6), is used in the simulation from the CT sample to local model 4, as shown in Table 3 and Figure 7. Table 3.
Effective modulus from analytical formulation in test.2
Modulus (GPa)
EP/Silica (91/9) EP/Silica/PR (91/7/2) EP/Silica/PR (91/4.5/4.5) EP/Silica/PR (91/2/7) EP/ PR (91/9)
3.79 3.50 3.16 2.86 2.63
PR: powdered rubber.

Based on the load–displacement test results for the SiO2/rubber/epoxy specimen in Ref. [2], the critical loads, or the peak loads, are obtained and the curve of critical load versus SiO2 volume fraction is fitted. For the 2D FE model of CT sample, the fitted critical load is (7)Pc=160.2-13.33Vp+0.86Vp2 where the total volume fraction of particles (SiO2 and rubber) is 9 vol.%, and the unit of SiO2 volume fraction, Vp, is percentage (%).

St. Venant’s principle implies that stress concentration effects are localized around the concentration; therefore, if the boundaries of the local model are far enough away from the stress concentration, reasonably accurate results can be calculated in the local model. Due to the large difference in dimensional scales from the CT sample to the nanoscale RVE model, several local models with smaller and smaller sizes are built in the present study, as shown in Figure 7. First, the half CT FE model is analyzed based on an effective modulus of elasticity obtained from equations (4)–(6), then, displacements on the internal boundaries in the global model having identical coordinates as the external boundaries of local model 1 are extracted and used as applied loads on local model or submodel-1. Similar methods are used through local model 2 to local model 5, respectively. Through data transfer among several local models, the size of the smallest model, submodel-5, approach the nanoscale.

In actual case, the distribution of nanoparticles around the crack tip should be random. Different particle distribution will slightly affect the local stress distribution, but it will not significantly affect the overall trend of mechanical properties and the accuracy of the overall model data, because high stress concentration at the crack tip is more important in fracture analysis. Thus, in this article, one configuration of particles is selected for the nanoscale analysis, to study the interaction between the crack tip, particles and matrix.

sec.title: Definition of debonding criteria
sec.p: In the smallest local model 5, three-phase FE models including the contact pairs between particle and matrix are built, and two kinds of interphase and different particle volume fractions are considered. It is believed that such models reflect the real condition more accurately than the conventional perfect bonding models.

Particle debonding from matrix, with zero-thickness interphase, is considered in this paper. Here particle debonding is achieved by VCCT. Interfaces, with zero thickness, debonded with respect to the energy criterion. When the critical strain energy release rate of interphase is met, interfacial debonding will occur. The critical strain energy release rate of interphase between the rubber particle and matrix is much larger than that between nanosilica and matrix.

sec.title: Fracture toughness and prediction of crack propagation path
sec.p:
In materials science, fracture toughness is a property which describes the ability of a material containing a crack to resist fracture and is one of the most important properties of any material for virtually all design applications. In plane strain structure, the fracture toughness for mode I, KIC, can be obtained in ABAQUS. The simulation results by multi-scale modeling technology are compared with test results from Ref. [2] in Figure 8 and Table 4. Predictions in submodel-5 are seen to be in reasonably good agreement with test results. Figure 8.
KIC versus volume fractions of rubber particles by multi-scale modeling.
Table 4.
Comparisons of fracture toughness from test2 and submodel-5.
KIC (MPa·m1/2)
EP/Silica (91/9) EP/Silica/PR (91/7/2) EP/Silica/PR (91/4.5/4.5) EP/Silica/PR (91/2/7) EP/ PR (91/9)
Test2 0.80 ± 0.03 0.83 ± 0.02 0.89 ± 0.02 0.95 ± 0.04 1.01 ± 0.04
Submodel-5 0.792 0.839 0.907 0.970 0.995
PR: powdered rubber.

Under the critical tensile loads Pc, the high-stress areas in CT sample, from macroscale to nanoscale, are shown in Figure 9(a)–(f), respectively. The condition of crack extension depends on both the stress level and the failure strength of the matrix, interphase and particles materials. On macroscale, stress concentration appears at the crack tip, as shown in Figure 9(a). On nanoscale, the Figure 9(b)–(f) shows the stress distributions in submodel-5 with different particle volume fractions. Each shows that the relative high-stress areas appear in matrix material, which connects the crack tip to the nearby particles and particles to each other, which means the new extension path will start from the initial crack and follow relative high-stress areas in matrix due to the high stress and low ultimate strength of matrix material. Also, the debonding will occur on the interface between matrix and the particle. Figure 9.
Distribution of Von Mises stress near the crack tip: (a) CT sample (9 vol.% silica); (b) Submodel-5 (9 vol.% rubber); (c) Submodel-5 (2 vol.% silica + 7 vol.% rubber); (d) Submodel-5 (4.5 vol.% silica + 4.5 vol.% rubber); (e) Submodel-5 (7 vol.% silica + 2 vol.% rubber); (f) Submodel-5 (9 vol.% silica).

list-item.p: From equations (1)–(3), it is shown that the effective modulus of the nanoparticle-reinforced epoxy is dependent on the volume fraction of particle. The effective elastic modulus and tensile strength of nanocomposites increase with increasing volume fraction of particles, as shown in Tables 1 and 2. Test results of nanocomposites for modulus are in good agreement with these analytical formulation predictions, especially for Halpin-Tsai model. Compared with the experimental results of SiO2/epoxy, the proposed RVE model based on micromechanics can accurately predict the relative tensile properties, versus volume fraction of particles, which is shown in Figure 4(a) and (b).

From Figure 5, it can be seen some fluctuations exist during elastic and weak plastic stages, which may be caused by particle debonding, while larger fluctuations after the failure point result from crack propagation.

Figure 6 shows the whole failure path of RVE containing particle debonding, crack initiation, growth and intersection. It can be seen that, cracks bypass the encountered particles during propagation, which can extend the crack path and absorb more energy, revealing the toughening and strengthening mechanism.

From Figure 8, it is found that the accuracy depends on the size of virtual crack. With the decrease of virtual crack and element size near the crack tip, the predicted value of KIC decreases and gradually approaches the test results, and the lowest-scale submodel-5 has the highest simulation accuracy. Besides, it is found that the relative improvement of fracture toughness, KIC, increase with increasing volume fraction of rubber, but the amplitude of improvement decreases gradually.

Compared with test results in Ref. [2], the multi-scale method can efficiently predict the fracture toughness of nanoparticles-reinforced composites accurately, as shown in Figure 8. Most of the predicted values have good accuracy compared with test values as shown in Table 3.

Figure 9(b)–(f) shows that at least some of the fracture energy is dissipated by the fracture of epoxy resin near the crack tip and the debonding on the interface between the particle and matrix. The existence of particles and the crack tip produce stress concentration, which determines the potential crack propagation path, as shown in high stress areas appear in matrix of Figure 9(b)–(f). At the same time, it is found that the stress and strain on the particles is relatively small, which implies that no particle fracture mechanism takes place when the sample ruptures. Instead, the particles can block the extension of cracks in the matrix and make the cracks bow around the particles.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The effective modulus and tensile strength of particle-reinforced nanocomposites can be calculated by the proposed FEM for different particle volume fractions, with good accuracy compared with the tensile test results. The present multi-scale modeling based on micromechanics can be used to estimate the fracture properties and investigate interactions of the crack tip and particles, as well as potential crack growth region.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
